name: substratum
content:
substratum noun [C]
(LOWER LAYER)
Add to word list
Add to word list
geology
  specialized a layer of rock, soil, or similar material that is below another layer: A substratum of clay kept moisture close to the topsoil. They planned to sink over twenty-five deep boreholes into the ground to assess the substrata.
a part or layer of something that is below another part or layer: Apply a substratum of lash powder and then quickly seal with a stroke of mascara. "Underclass" is used by sociologists to mean a substratum of society somewhere below the working class.
More examplesFewer examplesThe spade dug up three inches of black soil with a substratum of yellow mud and clay.The rich alluvial soils provide an ideal substratum for growing rice. The Valmiki community is a substratum of the Dalit caste.There's a whole substratum of administrative positions.

substratum noun [C]
(BASIS)
something important from which something else develops, but that is not immediately obvious: There is a broad substratum of truth in what she says. Would a jury conclude that a sufficient factual substratum existed for the comment?
More examplesFewer examplesMany of the ancient mythical tales have a substratum of historical fact.There was a substratum of good feeling in her.The novel has a solid substratum of well-conceived minor characters.
